div.head: CHAPTER XVII.
THE BELEAGUERED FORCE IN CAWNPORE
div.p: THE despairing tone in which Mrs. Fletcher spoke, at the same time pressing her little one in her arms, assured Bessie Hope that it was in vain to urge any course which looked like seeking danger. She flung her arms around her sister's neck, as she said, "Be calm!--OH, be calm, dear Annie! The same providence that has protected us till now, will protect us still! You recollect the counsel we have?--the counsel that so well accorded with your own thoughts and feelings? It was to seek the route to Cawnpore!
"Yes. My husband is there!" said Annie. "On!--on!--Oh, let us on!"

"Alas, I know not the path! Yet let me think! Oh, how the hurry of these events drive things from the memory? Did not some one say that by following the course of this little stream, we should find it again across the high-road, or track to Cawnpore?" inquired Bessie.
"Yes!--yes! I heard that!" hastily replied Mrs. Fletcher.

"Oh, then, in the name of heaven, let us not seek any modes of conveyance but that which nature has furnished us with! Come, dear Annie, we will follow the bank of the stream of foot; and we shall be far less likely to be seen than if we rode on horseback! Let me carry the little one?"
"No!--no! Not while life if mine! No!--no!"

There was a strange and almost maniacal manner about Mrs. Fletcher as she clung to her child, and would not let even her much-loved sister, Bessie, aid her with it, which gave to the heart of the young girl a pang of alarm, that possibly the fearful events of the last few hours and days, had affected the intellect of her sister. She strove to soothe her by words of hopefulness and loving kindness!--by talking of possible meetings in days to come with those she had loved so dearly!--and the sounds of the sobs of the young mother, as her poor heart felt the soft influence of the kind intention, fell gratefully on the ears of Bessie Hope , and encouraged her in exhorting her sister to bear up against the numerous perils that surrounded them, and yield not to the almost overwhelming pressure of misfortune.

And so these desolate ones proceeded sadly on their way, with a hostile country around them, and the bright stars of heaven above them--with no one to cheer them--no arms, even could they have used them, wherewith to defend themselves--little knowledge of their route--everything to dread, and so little of hope mingled in the bitter draught of their sad destiny, that they seemed as if led by some invisible chain to execution. And so delicately nurtured, too, as they had been, so carressed, and--if we may use the expression--so pampered in the lap of luxury, that even the winds of heaven had not been permitted to visit their cheeks too roughly, ow all unfitted they were to buffet with the world, and encounter the lowering storm that was bursting over India!

The way was rought; long branches crawled along the rugged route, and entangling themselves among the feet of the poor wayfarers, both wounded and impeded them. Now and then, either it was real, or fancy depicted the gliding motion of some snake-like reptile, as, with a shivering speed, it shot away from before them. Then they came to a portion of the river's bank, which was a kind of quick-sand, deep into which they trod at every step, while the water oozed and bubbled up around their feet.
And they heard no sound but the occasional cry of a jackal in the woods, and, now and then, the faint twittering of insect things, disturbed amid the brushwood close to the stream!
"Sister?--dear Bessie," said Mrs. Fletcher, "I repent me--"
”Of what, Annie?”

"I refused to let you take the little one. You are stronger than I am!--you may reach some place of safety, and save this dear one and yourself! Teach it to pray for its poor mother!--to bless her name! Say that--that--"
"Annie! Annie!--what in the name of heaven mean you?" exclaimed Bessie, in a tone of alarm and consternation, as Mrs. Fletcher suddenly stopped and despairingly cried,--
"I can go no further! Leave me here to die! Take the dear one and go on--"

"Never!--never in life, dear Annie! We will surely, live or die together; and even now--look!--what is that admit those trees? I see a twinkling light! There may be some human habitation, and we may get shelter! Oh, surely, let what wars the Hindoos may wage against men, they cannot deny women and children! There, dear Annie!--do you not see it? A light like a large star. It shines among some bushes so serenely, and so hopefully! Strive yet a little! You are better now! You walk bravely! That is well! Ah, dear Annie, in some happy home, with all those whom we love about us, who shall say that we may not yet talk over the events of this now fearful-seeming night! On!--on!--see, the light brightens! There is a hut or bungalow of some sort! They will not be Sepoys, there, but ryots--possibly some zemindar, or proprietor. We shall have a a welcome, dear sister! Yet a little further! Think of your husband; and that every step is et nearer and nearer still to him, and how he longs to hold you and this dear little one to his heart: and see, the river now winds to the left! It is to cross the road as we have been told. Cheer up, hear heart, and all may yet be well!"
Thus encouraging--thus entreating and aiding poor Mrs. Fletcher's faltering steps with what strength she had, Bessie played the ministering angel to her suffering sister!
The light they had seen moving among the trees brightened as they approached it ; and they saw that it streamed

from the open casement of a low-roofed bungalow, which, either was the isolated dewlling of some zemindar, or the commencement of a native village. A small cleared space after they had passed a littlr way from the river to the right among a clump of trees, brought them to a ruinous-looking shed at some little distance from the bungalow, and there they paused ; for a dog began to bark furiously, and they dreaded to advance.

"Hush!" said Bessie; and she could not but tremble as she spoke, despite all the hopeful things she had said to her sister,--"hush, dear Annie! Let us wait here for a moment! The barking of the dog may bring out some one; and then we shall perhaps be able to judge better, if it be safe to ask the hospitality we so much need!"
"You tremble, Bessie?"
"Oh, no, no,--that is, I am chilled! The night air is cold even in India. Oh, hush! Crouch down here in the shadow of the trees. See--see, some one has come out!"

The alarm brought to the door of the bungalow a Hindoo, who carried with him a lighted brand of resinous wood, which he held above his head with one hand, while he shaded his eyes with the other, and stroveto pierce the obscurity beyond him to see if any one was approaching to account for the alarm that the dog had given. The appearance of this man was wild and ferocious, and the lower part of his face was bound up with a white cloth, on which there were dark stains as if of blood. The handle of a creese, or dagger, projected from his girdle; and take him or all in all, his appearance was certainly not calculated to inspire the sisters with faith in any appeal to his benevolence.
"Down!--down" they heard him say to the dog. "The curse of bad spirits be upon you!"
The animal was silent.
The Hindoo then muttered something to himself; and placing the torch in the cleft of a tree, close at hand, he retired hastily into the bungalow.
"Annie," whispered Bessie, "I will not trust that man! Can you, by any possibility, walk further?"
"I will try! Oh, yes--yes! Save me, Bessie, save me!"
"Be calm! This way!--this way!"

Even as Bessie spoke, the man came out of the bungalow againl and this time he had a cloth about his head and shoulders, and a musket in his hand. Bessie drew her sister back hastily among the trees, and fear for a few moments overcome all sense of fatigue in the frame of Mrs. Fletcher, as they took their way through briars and brushwood, whither they scarcely knew; but they suddenly came to a low paling, a portion of which was composed of twisted branches of the banian tree. Indeed, it was rather a kind of natural hedge, with numerous large openings among the branches of the shrubs and trees that formed it, than a paling, although art had evidently assisted at its formation.

By a sort of instinct, Bessie dragged her sister through one of the gaps; and they then observed a little outhouse or building, no doubt devoted to some agricultural purpose connected with the surrounding rice and indigo fields. The feeling, that any shelter was a short of security, so long as it had a roof to it, prompted Bessie to urge her sister to enter this place; and stooping low, to get through its doorway, they found themselves evidently in a fruit storehouse, the floor of which was thickly strewn with dried grass.

The odour of the mango, the pomegranate, the guava, the plaintain, and the papaya came strongly on their senses; and Mrs. Fletcher sunk, with a deep sigh, in a state of utter exhaustion on the soft grass, which had been laid some foor or so in depth uponthe hard-beaten earthen floor.

Bessie made an endeavour to fasten the frail door by which they had entered the place; but she quickly found how futile was such an attempt, so she knelt by it, and with every sense wound up by the occasion to a painful stretch of acuteness, she strove to look into the darkness beyond, and to listen for any sound that might indicate approaching danger.

A strange creaking noise, like the show progress of wheels over some hard dry road, reached her ears: and then the dog again barked furiously, and she heard the animal silenced by the voice of the Hindoo. The creaking noise of wheels continued; and then to the surprise, as well as the joy, of Bessie, she suddently heard an English voice cry "Halt!"

Bessie uttered a cry, and sprang to the side of her sister, whom she embraced and kissed with almost delirious pleasure, saying with catching breath and tearful tones, "There is help! Oh, there is help and dear companionshop without! I hear the blessed tones of England! Be hopeful and happy, dear Annie! Did I not say that all would be well? I will go see them; and you will hear the deat tones, and see the honest faces of our countrymen!"
Without waiting for a moment's, reply, Bessie rushed fromm the outhouse, and called out, "Help, here!--help, me! I heard an English voice!"

"Who is that?" said some one apparently in pain; and then before another word could be spoken, Hindoo came through the trees with the torch, and holding it up in his left hand, while with his right he clutched a very showy sword, the hilt of which seemed to sparkle as if set with precious stones, he not only gazed upon the scene before him, himself, but enabled Bessie Hope to do likewise.

It was a strange scene, and, at the first glance, difficult to comprehend. There was a small, half-covered country-waggon, or rather car, drawn by a couple of tired-looking bullocks. The cart was half-full of hay and Indian grasses, on which, pale and faint-looking, lay two English officers, one in a rich cavalry uniform, stained with blood, and torn and hacked in many places ; and the other in that of an officer of the line. Both of these officers had revolvers, which they presented over the rickety side of the cart, although they seemed hardly to have strength to pull the triggers of them, had there been occasion to do so.

But the most curious part of the cavalcade, if it may be called such, was its escort, which consisted of a cavalry soldier, with his head and left arm bound up in bloodstained rages, and a cavalry sabre in his right hand; while a young and frank-looking girl of some twenty years of age--her face pale with anxiety, but a look of courage and determination in her blue eyes that was a joy to see--brought a soldier's musket to the charge and stood resolutely on the defensive. Her dress was picturesque, for she wore a foraging cap with a gold band and tassel, from beneath which, in long wavy masses, escaped her fair hair, which was of that beautiful colour called golden in the north, and upon which the light from the Hindoo's torch shone as if there were literally threads of gold interwoven among it. A scarf of tartan was wound tightly about her, and set off her fine figure to advantage. Her atititude combined grace with dignity; and there was a chivalric courage about her, as she there stood with the musket at the charge, and the bayonet gleaming in the flickering light from the Hindoo's torch, that would have won the admiration of a painter.

So suddenly had all these parties confronted each other-- the cart and its occupants and guard, Bessie Hope and the Hindoo--that for a moment or two, no one uttered a word. But the light had flashed upon the fair face of Bessie, and one of the wounded officers cried out, "English ladies here? Is there a party? Have you guards? If not, would to God we were in a better condition to aid you!"
"We are but two!" said Bessie. "Myself and Mrs. Fletcher, my sister, the wife of Major Fletcher. We had sought temporary shelter in yonder outhouse--"
"Halt!" cried the young girl with the musket, suddenly. "Another step, and I fire!"

All eyes were now directed to where she now presented the musket; and they saw the Hindoo, who had made a few steps toward the outhouse, with his hand on the handle of his creese, for he had sheathed his rich sword, crouching down, and showing, through his retracted lips, his teeth with a look of snarling rage.

The tone of the girl was unmistakably Scotch; and it had a kindly sound with it to the heart of Bessie. The Hindoo only for a moment suffered his countenance to wear a look of baffled hate; and then, with the facile cunning of his race, he recovered himself and salaamed low, as he said, "I am the humble slave of the great Sahibs! I live but in the light of the eyes of my lords, the Feringhee chiefs! What am I? Nothing! Let my lords order! It is for me to obey! Great is the goodness of the Ma'am Sahib with the musket!"
"Disarm him, Wootton!" said the other officer to the cavalry soldier. "I don't at all like the fellow's looks! Be quick about it!"

The wounded cavalry soldier quickly deprived the Hindoo of his weapons; and covered as he was by the musket of the young girl, he saw the wisdom of not resisting, although the expression of his countenance, while the operation was going on, was anything but amiable.
"It is done, sir!" said the soldier, as he saluted the officer who had given him the order.
"And well done, too!" said the officer, faintly. "How weak I am, Hargrave! I fear I shall not be able to get on any further!"

The other officer, who was addressed as Hargrave made an attempt to rally his own strength, although it was nearly as far gone as that of his companion, and addressing Bessie, he said, "Is it possible, think you, with any regard to safety, to get a night's repose here?"

"Alas! I know not!" said Bessie. "I and my sister are but fugitives like yourselves, and we, too, are weary and would fain rest! My name is Hope, and we escaped, with friends, from Delhi ; but meeting a force of Sepoys, are all scattered, if not murdered, but ourselves. You will permit us, gentlemen, to join your party! We are so very friendless!"

"Surely, surely!" cried both the officers, and at that moment there was heard the sound of footsteps through the little wood, and pale and anxious, with the child clasped to her breast, Mrs. Fletcher appeared. At the first sight of the uniforms of the cavalry soldier and the the officers, she uttered a cry of joy, and the tears gushed from her eyes, as she exclaimed,
"Saved! saved! Oh, Bessie, we are saved! Thank heaven, here are dear English faces!"

"We will do what we can to aid you," said the senior of the two officers; "but you see, ladies, that we are in poor case ourselves! We were both badly wounded at an out station, and had to escape the best way we could; and but for this heroic girl here, and my servant, Wootton, we must ere have perished! We are trying to make our way to Lucknow! We will try, after a rest, if we can crawl along on foot, and you shall have the cart to yourselves. It only holds two!"
"No, no!" said Mrs. Fletcher, as she trembled with fresh apprehension. "You are both wounded, and it will be our provinces to tend you as bst we may, and heaven will help us all!"

And now the young girl to whom the officer pointed as so gallant a friend and preserver of the party, handed her musket to the soldier, and advancing kindly to Mrs. Fletcherr, she said, "You are weary and faint! Let me carry the little one for you! Nay, you may trust me with it; for though but a soldier's daughter, I have the heart of a dear countrywoman of your own I fancy--Hope is a good Scotch name!"

With a gentleness that won the heart of Mrs. Fletcher, the young girl took the infant and kissed its pale face. They saw a tear fall upon its cheek, as she murmured, "Poor little one! These are sad times, indeed, for the young and the helpless!"

Sad times for all!" said the officer; "but you must not turn nurse, my good girl! What should we have done without your bold spirit and ready arm? You have saved us more than once from death! You are a heroine, Jessie!

The girl blushed, and in answer to Mrs. Fletcher, she drew herself rather proudly to her full height, as she said, "My name is Jessie Campbell! They call me Highland Jessie, because I come from dear old Scotland, the land of the mountain and the flood! I have a woman's heart, but the spirit of my race at times nerves my arm! I have brothers in the service, and there is one who loves me better than a sister in the Highland regiment! They know not that I am in India; but I was alone in the Highlands, father and mother were both with the dead, and I was desolate! They sunk to rest on the bleak mountain saide, without a home or a shelter from the storm! Our home of generations was swept from the face of the land, that the wild deer might be the sole inhabitant of the old glens and the hills, as it was before man raised his shieling to the sky! All were gone--brothers to the wars, and Donald with them! I have followed! An officer's lady brought me over as attendant to her children; and I am here now, doing, I hope, my duty, and living with the dear thought that I shall see the kind faces of my kindred yet in this strange land, and that some happy day I shall hear the pibroch of my own Donald! Oh, you should see him in his martial array!--so proud his step, so gallant his bearing, so tender his heart! His blue eyes sparkle in the light, and there is music in his voice!-- Donald, my own Donald, who told me that he loved me beneath the fair skies of bonny Scotland! God's blessing be his shield!"

The young Highland girl spoke with rapidity. Her feelings carried her away, and there was a flush of vivid excitement upon her face, as she now dashed away her gathering tears; and, bending with a graceful action before her listeners, she added, "Oh, pardon me! I should not say what I say, but when the old home in the Highlands looms before my mind, I am near distraught, and out of the fulness of my heart, my lips speak!"

Bessie Hope was deeply touched by the noble words and graceful dignity of Highland Jessie. She sprang forward, and casting her arms around her, she said, "Be our friend, Jessie! Be our dear friend, for such we will esteem you; and if ever fortune smiles upon us again, and these troublous times pass away, no one shall be more dear and honoured with us, than you!"

"She is a noble girl!" cried the officer, while a faint flush on his pale face shouwed how deeply he felt what he said. "She is a noble girl! My friend, Colonel Hargrave, and myself, owe our lives to her ten times over!"
"God bless her!" said Colonel Hargrave, faintly; "and if this is my last hour of life, as I almost fear it is, I shall die your grateful debtor, Jessie!"
"No, no!" cried Jessie. "Live on! Oh, cheer up; we will have rest yet! Some hut or house is near at hand, and Wootton and I will still be your guards!"
"To be sure, your honours!" said the cavalry sol-
dier. "Never give in, Colonel! All will be right your honour, yet ; and I shall live to see you yet with your regiment! Excuse a poor fellow for trying to cheer your honour!"
Colonel Hargrave tried to say something, and then, with a deep sigh, his head fell back, and a deathlike paleness came across his face.
"God bless you, my dear friend!" said the cavalry officer, as he clasped Hargrave's hand.
"Water! water!" said Jessie. "Is there any? He is but faint from the loss of blood!"
"On my eyes be it!" said the Hindoo. "I will fetch water for the Sahib!
"And I will go with you," said Wootton, "to help you, in case you should forget to come back!"

"I am my lord's slave, and if the great Sahibs will cross the threshold of my dwelling, it is theirs, and all within it. Who am I? Bosh! May the graves of my kindred be defiled if I speal not the truth. May I be the brother of asses, and may evil ones be about me, if I speak ill!"

div.head: CHAPTER XVIII.
THE ATTACK.--THE WELL, AND THE RESCUE.
div.p: THE hut of the Hindoo, who, with such doubtful faith, led the way for the wounded officers, was soon reached, and with a great affectation of hospitality, he gling its door wide, to admit his visitors.
"Enter, Lord Sahib!" he said. "Enter the humble house of the lowest of your slaves!"

The cart was stopped; and with difficulty, for he was badly hurt, Colonel Lane--for he was the wounded cavalry officer--alighted. The infantry colonel was still insensible; and Wootton carefully assisted Jessie to lift him from the vehicle, while Colonel Lane, with his revolver in his hand, kept an eye on the Hindoo, who would have volunteered his aid, but Highland Jessie warned him off.

The interior of the hut was rude in the extreme: but it was more spacious than it had at first seemed to be; and there was an inner apartment to it, as well as a sort of loft in the roof, whcih appeared to be reached by a rude ladder made of untrimmed pieces of wood, with the bark still on them.

The Hindoo busied himself in the preparation of a couch for Colonel Hargrave, composed of grass, and some rough country cloth laid over it; and from the inner room he brought a pitcher of water, which Jessie sprinkled on the face of the insensible officer, as well as inducing him to take a small portion between his lips. With a sigh, then, Colonel Hargrave opened his eyes.
"Where am I?" he said faintly.

"All right!" said Colonel Lane. "Cheer up! you will soon be stronger, if we can only get you something to eat, to repair the weakness you are suffering from. You have lost so much blood, my dear friend!"
Colonel Hargrave pressed his hand, as he said, in a low tone, "And you too!"
"Oh, don't think of me! I--I--am--all right."
The ghastly paleness of Colonel Lane alarmed Bessie, and she cried, "God help us all! Oh, what can we do?
"My dear--young--lady, we--we are famishing, almost, as well as being wounded. If we could only get some food!"

"Here!" cried Jessie, as she appeared from a rummage of the hut, and presented on a wooden dish, some rice and milk, and some cooked fruits she had found. "Here is food. It seems all the place affords."

The Hindoo made a gesture of dissent; and, going to a remote corner, he tilted up an earthen vessel, and took from beneath it, on a European plate, an ample portion of a favourite Indian dish called kitchri, which is compounded of curried fowl, the flesh of the young goat, chillies, and other matters according to taste.
"May your slace be favoured in your eyes!" he said. "Here is that which the King of Delhi might covet."

The famished officers looked eagerly at the food, and then, with a bow to Bessie and her sister, Colonel Lane said, "When you are all done, we will begin. Jessie, will you preside? for, my good girl, you must want food as badly as we can."
"Oh, no! no!" said Jessie, "you are wounded; eat first. Do not pause, for we may be all in peril here."

In good truth, there was no time to stand on any ceremony; and, since anything in the shape of spoons, or other modes of conveying the viands from the dish to the mouth, there were none, each one helped himself and herself as best they could with the help of some chaffratees or native cakes, which the Hindoo produced in pretty good abundance.
"May my good lords be strengthened!" he said, when he saw that they had cleared the dishes. "Would that I had couches worthy of the repose of Sahibs; but here is all!"
Certainly, the sleeping accomodation was not very inviting, since, with the exception fo the extemporaneous couch on whichlay Colonel Hargrave, there was nothing but the bare floor for any one else.
"I am better!" said the Colonel, as he slowly rose. "Do you, Mrs. Fletcher, with your little one, take this couch, rude as it is."
"Nay," said Colonel Lane; "we may find, no dount, some more grass, and can get some sort of resting-place for the ladies. Our stay here, at best, can be but brief."
"My lord's words are wisdom!" said the Hindoo. "I will throw down dried grass in abundance from above."

He indicated the loft as he spoke; and without waiting for any reply to the proposition, he coolly and quietly ascended the rough ladder, and disappeared through the hole in the inner roof or ceiling of the hut.
"I don't half like to lose sight of him, your honours," said the soldier.

The little party started at this idea, and they all looked with anxiety towards the rude ladder, up which their unwilling host had ascended. Twenty or thirty seconds elapsed, which, to their anxieties, appeared like as so many minutes, but no dried grass or Hindoo appeared.

"He plays us false!" said Jessie, as she sprung toward the ladder; but, before she could reach it, it was suddenly pulled up from above; and in a wild, screeching voice, the Hindoo shouted, "Death to the Feringhee!--death! death!"

Then ensued a crashing sound, and the fall of a heavy body just outside the hut. The Hindoo had broken his way through the frail roof, and allowed himself partly to foll and partly to jump to the ground outside. Another wild yell proclaimed his exultation at his escape; and then something struck the door heavily on the outside, and before any of the party in the hut could resolve upon a course of action, they heard the monotonous sounds of a native drum at no great distance without; and the gleam of some torches came in, through cracks and orifices, in the little wooden structure, quite eclipsing the faint light of the miserable lamp, composed of twisted cloth dipped in oil, which did duty in the hut.
"We are betrayed!" said Colonel Lane
"And lost!" said Hargrave.
"No! no!" cried Highland Jessie,--"no! no! There may be time yet! They are only villagers! To the cart--to the cart, and we may yet escape!"

She flew to the door and tried to open it outwards, which it was constructed to do, but it was evident that the Hindoo had succeeded in fastening it in some wat, for it resisted both Jessie and Wootton, as if it had been a solid rock.
"I know what it is," said the cavalry man. "The rascal has got the end of a felled tree against it."

Mingling with these words from Wootton, there came such yells and shouts from without, as might well appal the stoutest hearts; and it was evident that a throng of infuriated villagers, or escaped thieves from some of the revolted stations, were rapidly approaching the hut.

The situation of the small party of Europeans was indeed most critical, and they might well look at each other as persons destined to death. Bessie flung her arms around her sister, and for the first time since that horrible escape from Delhi, seemed to give way to despair. The lips of Mrs. Fletcher moved as though she would speak, but inarticulate sounds, mingled with sobs, alone escaped her.
The two officers forgot, in the strong excitement of the moment, their debility from wounds ; and, pale as they were, they stood erect, and listening to the sounds without.
It was Jessie who broke the terrible silence of the party int he hut.
"Despair not!" she said. "There is yet life, and there is, therefore, yet hope! The doopr may be secured within, surely?"

She sprung forward to the door of the hut, and the cavalry soldier accompanied her. They found that there were some strong wooden staples in the door-post, and at the back of the door, through which a bar might be passed, if they could find one to answer the purpose; but no such thing presented itself. The Hindoos without raised another shout of triumph, and a shot came through the frail framework of the house, and lodged on the opposite partition.,

The officers immediately faced the door, and Colonel Lane said, sternly, "We shall be sacrificed, but we will sell our lives dearly! Would to heaven that our deaths could, by any means, be the deliverance of these helpless ones! Ladies, we bid you adieu! God help you, for we can do no more in this emergency!"

A rush of Hindoos from without now shook the frail building; and then they heard the unmistakable voice of the proprietor of the hut call out, "Remove the log! remove the log! Sons of burnt fathers, what by you by that senseless effort? Remove the log, and the door opens!"
"No!" said Highland Jessie, as with the impulse of the moment she seized the musket and slid it thorugh the stapes in the door and door-post,--"no, not yet!"

A loud shout proclaimed the removal of the log of timber that had kept the door from opening, and then a yell of disappointment, as those without found that it was still fast, notwithstanding all their furious shaking at it.
"Thank you, Jessie," said Colonel Lane. "This is a respite, if not a reprieve, my good girl!"

"Fire!" cried a voice from without; and immediately an irregular discharge of musketry ensued. The whole party within the hut stooped low, and the bullets flew over their heads, crashing through the frail boarding of which the building was composed.

"Hold!" said Bessie, as the two officers were about to return the fire by random shots with their revolvers, through the thin planking of which the front of the hut was composed,--"hold! Do you hear that?"

The reverbation of the firing had ceased, and now a dull, heavy knocking at a part of the wall some few feet from the door, was plainly heard, and then a kind of shutter, about two feet square, was removed from the outside, and the face of the Hindoo proprietor of the wretched little abode appeared, distorted by passion, and brandishing an axe in his hand. It was but for an instant that he so showed himsef, for, by the dim light within the place, he saw Colonel Lane raise his revolver to a direct line with his head.
The sharp report of the pistol and the disappearance of the Hindoo were simultaneous; but the shout he raised when he dropped to the ground without, showed that he was unhurt.

At this instant Bessie uttered a cry of alarm, and the whole party turning in the direction where she and Mrs. Fletcher were, they saw both the sisters pointing with excited gestures to the opening in the roof, leading to the loft, and from which appeared to be dangling some small dark object, which in another moment dropped lightly to the floor, and then springing with a graceful bound to its feet, showed itself to be a young child, wrapped round the middle with a red cloth, but otherwise perfectly unattired. The slight agile form and the sparkling eyes of the little creature, who could not be above six or seven years of age, together with a look of intense surprise on its facr, and a tremor of its libs, which made some gold or gilt baugles clatter musically together, precluded the notion of either espial or denial from it; but Colonel Lane stepped forward, and laying a hand upon the arm of the little intruder, he said, in Hindostanee, "Who are you and where do you come from?"
"Rao Patan" is my father," said the child, in soft, gentle accents. "I am come home; but he was not within, so I crept to sleep above. Salaam,Sahib."
The child made the usual salaam of the natives to Europeans of rank, and then folding her arms across her breast, she stood submissive and silent.
"Fire!" cried the voice again from without.
An instinctive feeling of humanity induced Colonel Lane to press his hand upon the shoulder of the Hindoo child, as he said, "Stoop!--stoop, or you are hit!"

Again the irregular discharge of musketry from without crashed through the hut, and then, with a rush, some half-dozen Hindoos clambered to the small opening that had been made in the wall, evidently intent on forcing an entrance that way.
Both the officers fired their revolvers, and Wootton plied his sabre with energy. One of the enemy dropped
inside the hut, mortally wounded; and after rolling over twice, and making frantic grasps at the dried grass on the floor, he straightened out his limbs with a spasmodic jerk, and breathed his last.

The light in the hut had gone out; the concussion of the air from the shots, both within and without the place, had been too much for its frail existence; but through the numerous crevices in the walls of the building, the flare of the torces from without sent plenty of irregular and flickering light into the interior.

There was now a kind of lull in the attack; no doubt, the vigorous resistance effected by the revolvers of the officers and the sabre of Wootton taught the invaders of the little post caution. They tried now to accomplish, by treachery and stratagemm, what force--although it might succeed in doing--would cost them in the process more lives.
"Hearken, Sahibs!" said the Hindoo proprietor of the hut from without,--"hearken, Sahibs! Hand over what rupees you have, and you all go in safety. On my head be it!"

By the sound of the voice, this man was just below the little square opening in the wall; and scarcely had he done speaking, when Colonel Lane stepped up to the Hindoo child, and, whispering to her, "Have no fear! I will not harm you!" he sprang with her in his arms to the opening, and holding her up, so that the glare of the torces fell full ipon her face, he dried out, "Another shot, villains--and the life of this hostage is lost!"
The Hindoo uttered a shriek of despair.
"My child! my child!--my only one!" he cried. "I thought you far away. What evil destiny has brought you home? My Aza! my beautiful! My child!--my child! Mercy! Sahibs, mercy!"

"That will do," said the Colonel, as he placed the child in the care of Jessie; adding, "Look to her well. God knows I would not hurt a hair of her head, but the sight of her may yet save us from this dilemma."
"It may indeed," said Jessie, as she soothed the trembling child, who, at the moment, believed her destruction to be certain, notwithstanding the whispered words of the Colonel.
"Oh, no, no! Sahibs, do not kill me!" she sobbed. "I am only poor Aza, and have no mother. Father is cruel, but I do not want to die!"

A great contention appeared to be going on among the Hindoos composing the attacking party; and as they seemed too much engaged by it to take much notice of the party in the hut, Colonel Lane stepped to the opening in the wall to reconnoitre.

"A strange scene. They have placed their torches in clefts of trees, and the father of this child we have here is haranguing them with frantic speech and gestures. They appear to deride him--he falls on his knees, and clings to their feet! Don't you hear him shrieking? Now, they fall upon him--they will kill him! No--no! They bind him hands and feet--what a desperate struggle he makes! They overpower him!--and now they cast him among some bushes and brushwood. They seem to have gagged him, for he is quiet. I can guess it all! For his child's sake, he would make terms with us; but the others are too intent on our destruction, to be swayed by his fears and feelings, and so have got rid of his importunities for the time. They will commence the attack again--what is to be done?"
"The house is surrounded!" said Jessie, at this moment returning from an examination of the inner room.
"There is a strong force waiting in silence at the back, with the hope that we will attempt to force our way out in that direction, when they would fall upon us at once."
"Then all is lost!" said Bessie.
Mrs. Fletcher dropped gently to her knees, and tried to pray; but her words were only frantic calls upon heaven to spare her child.

With the sound of drums and shouts of triumph the Hindoo rabble now pressed onwards. They did not fire any more shots, but the twang of bow-strings might be heard; and soon a full red glare came in through the crevices of the hut, and sparks of fire began to fall through the opening in the ceiling leading to the loft.
The hut was in flames!

With a shout of exultation the Hindoos now retired to some twenty or thirty paces; and while the tomtoms were incessantly beaten, and a gong occasionally gave out its clashing sound, they seemed to wait the moment when the half-wasted Europeans must emerge and give themselves up to their foes.

The Hindoo child then, as if awakening from a dream, suddenly started to the side of Colonel Lane, and placing her hand in his, she said, as she looked in his face, "No! They are bad men without! They shall not burn the ma'am Sahibs and the officer Sahibs!
Come, come! Aza knows what to do! Come with Aza!--come!"
"What does she say and mean?" said Colonel Hargrave, who had not so good a knowledge of Hindostanee as his friend.
"She has some scheme of saving us, she thinks; and, child as she is, I fain would trust her."
"Come, oh, come!" said Aza. "Look! The fire!--the fire! They are bad men!"
"Lead on, in the name of heaven!" said the Colonel. "Follow, all of you! Who knows but this child may know some mode of escape which we, in our ignorance of the place, would never discover?"

With her little finger on her lips, the Hindoo child led the party into the inner room, and, at the further extremity of it, she tore down a piece of matting, and disclosed a narrow opening. The glare of the fire from the burning roof was more than sufficient to light up the spot, and they saw a kind of shed or outhouse, with a low, sloping roof, and on one side, but for some other pieces of matting which waved to and fro in the night air, open to the wood.
"Ah, that is well!" whispered the Colonel: we can escape by this way!"
"No!" said the Hindoo girl. "Look, Sahib!"

She drew the matting a little on one side, for the Colonel to look through, and he saw that in that direction, as well as in others, theplace was surrounded by the armed villagers waiting the result of the conflagration.
"How, then, can you help us?" he said.
Without a word, the girl hastily removed some loose pieces of wood that covered the middle of the floor, and disclosed the open mouth of a well.
"There, Sahib!"
"There? But the depth?"
Light and agile as a fawn, the Hindoo girl swung herself over the edge of the well, and disappeared.
"It is not deep," she said from below; "and there is but little water. The spring has departed long since, and the well is only of use when the great rains come.
In another moment she was by the side of the Colonel, having dexterously clambered up again by the rugged sides of the well.
"It is the only chance," said Colonel Lane.
"All saved!" said the girl, as she turned and gave a slight caress to Mrs. Fletcher's child. The action spoke volumes, and Mrs. Fletcher
"I would trust her to the death!" said Colonel Lane, in a voice of emotion.

The monotonous beating of the tom-toms continued, and the shout of the Hindoos welcomes the progress of the flames about the blazing hut. There was not a moment to loose, ad by one consent, the party made their way into the well. The depthj was not above ten or eleven feet, and there was about a foot of thick muddy water at the bottom; but that was all. A subterranean passage seemed to lead from the well, perhaps connecting it with some other spring. Wretched, and full of discomfort as this place was, it was a cool and welcome refuge from the blazing hut; and, with the assistance of Jessie and Wootton, the whole party were soon in the well.
"Aza, Aza!" cried the Colonel. "Alas! the poor child will be killed! She had better been with us!"
"God help us!" said Mrs. Fletcher: we shall yet die here for want of air!"

The well was completely dark, and a suffocating feeling came over the whole party. They heard the cries and yells of the Hindoos, as they, no doubt, gloated over the destruction of the Europeans, believing them to have miserably perished in the burning ruins of the hut.
"Help, help!" gasped Colonel Hargrave. "Air, or I perish!"
"Air! air!" shrieked Mrs. Fletcher.
"Your sword!" said Jessie. "Your sword, Wootton! Oh, quick!"

Dark as it was, the Highland girl got the long cavalry sword by the hilt, and, feeling her way up the rugged sides of the well, she thrust the weapon, with all her strength, through the mass of rubbish that covered its mouth. Again and again, with the energy of a last effort to save those with her and herself, she dashed the sword-blade upwards. There was a rumbling sound of displaced wood and smouldering fragments, and a rush of cooler air came down into the well.
